title: What would Heidegger say the essence of technology is? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, first he says in his essay Question Concerning Technology that the essence of technology is “nothing technological”, which basically means there is no machine, technique, or artifact that we can point to and say “that right there encapsulates what technology is.” By bracketing the technological from the essence of technology, Heidegger intends to setup a free relation to technologies essence I.e what technologies essence does to us, for us, with us, etc. (A brief caveat: In the essay, Heidegger is talking about the essence of modern technology which is markedly different for him than the essence of technology for the Ancients) Contrary to other answers, the essence of Modern technology, for Heidegger, is very much a mode revealing (“revealing” for Heidegger means revealing of truth). For one, it is a revealing of the natural world as something that can challenged by us to procure energy, resources, and other things of utility. One might think of damming a river in order to power turbines that produce electricity that can be used to power tools to excavate mines to extract ore for the very same types of tools that were used to extract it. In this example, we see that the very mode of revealing nature as something to be challenged forth only shows the truth of modern technology as this capacity to further order its own instruments for the sole purpose of continuing to challenge nature to produce energy, resources, and things of utility that can stored and called upon to repeat this whole process we call technological development. Heidegger’s worry is that the essence of modern technology— as this mode of revealing nature as something that can be challenged forth in order to further order develop the technological— is a mode of revealing (of truth) that excludes all other modes of revealing. Simply put, our obsession with technique, utility, and nature as this storehouse of energies and resources, blinds us to any other mode of revealing the truth about the world… such as the poetic, aesthetic, or ontological.

Heidegger was a member of the Nazi Party — even after they collapsed. Heidegger was thus a reactionary of a special degree. Thus, Heidegger was not an authentic Ontologist — on the contrary, he used Ontology as a rubric to support his reactionary politics and his support of Adolf Hitler. One of Heidegger’s positions was about technology — he was against it. The truly “authentic” life for Heidegger, was to go “back to Nature,” as far as the family farm. This “simple life” was how people were meant to live, in his ideal. Nevermind that this entailed the right of the first-born to own the land that the rest of his family — and outside community — would labor for the rest of their lives. This was normal, natural and “authentic” life for Heidegger. In the same way, for Heidegger, every nation should have a Fuhrer, a leader whom everybody follows without question, and for whom everybody must be willing to sacrifice everything — including life. Where does technology fit in? Heidegger, wrote about the Essence of Technology in his late article, The Question Concerning Technology (1977). There he says that the Essence of Technology “is by no means anything technological.” This is his typical Nazi double-speak. He continues: Everywhere we remain unfree and chained to technology, whether we passionately affirm or deny it. (Heidegger, 1977)Heidegger then defines technology by referring to the ancient Greeks: (1) technology is a means to an end; and (2) technology is a uniquely human activity. Period. He concludes that all technology is merely instrumental in human life. The key, then, is to use technology “properly,” and “spiritually” and to “master it.” What do these terms mean in 1977, however? He balks. In the Nazi period he was direct — “properly” meant “in the service of the Fuhrer”. Heidegger will delve deeper into Greek and Latin terms about technology — without changing his conclusions. The Essence of Technology always came down to the demand to “use the instrument properly, “ without describing “properly” in any detail. He ends his essay by asking the question again.

In a word, concealment. For any given thing; what it is is concealed in favor of what use it can be put to. The problem with technology is that it conceals its own fact of concealment. Every unconcealment is at the same time a concealment and every concealment is at the same time an unconcealment. If technological thinking conceals its own concealment, it conceals the very possibility of other kinds of unconcealment. So, your hand has two sides, if you put it face down you have unconcealed the back of your hand, while concealing the front of your hand, flip it over and vice versa. Now, what if you flipped your hand in such a manner that it showed you a way of handedness that at the same time prevented you from even thinking about the other side of your hand? What would it take to show you this forgotten aspect of Hands? The real danger of technology is that we then begin to apply technological thinking to ourselves and our fellow human beings this is one of the ways in which we become technologized.

Those who play with words are played by words. So any understanding in the “essence” of Heidegger’s perception can only be obtained when one goes beyond meanings of superficialities by words. The fundamental debate re “technology” concerns its instrumentality in the perpetual conflict of man’s quest in the duality of means and end. The conscious minds hence seek to analyze such an instrumentality so as to institutionalize either means or end for their functionality. That division of the intent introduces however unconsciously to the very departure from its true essence. The essence perceivable in realm of consciousness must be in upright agreement with that of man, from which man acts from without to within. In Heidegger’s great depiction of Greek Temple, man in the state of being without finds his outlook in the state of being within in the vast emptiness that gives shapes and form, thoughts and ideas, and meanings and values. In between being and becoming lies that which enables this undefinable subtlety of finesses that finds man’s entirety. So in this timeless making perphas seeds the creation of technology which instrumentality is of man in finding his outlook from within the emptiness of Greek Temple in no being nor becoming.
